data.title: Ishiro Honda
data.meta_description: “Monsters are tragic beings. They are born too tall, too strong, too heavy. They are not evil by choice. That is their tragedy. They do not attack people because they want to, but because of their size and strength, mankind has no other choice but to defend himself. After several stories such as...
data.text:
Ishiro Honda Occupation/Role Director, writer, editor Birthday May 7, 1911 Date of Death February 28, 1993 Birthplace Yamagata Prefecture, Japan First Work Chocolate and Soldiers (1938) Notable Work Godzilla (1954)

“Monsters are tragic beings. They are born too tall, too strong, too heavy. They are not evil by choice. That is their tragedy. They do not attack people because they want to, but because of their size and strength, mankind has no other choice but to defend himself. After several stories such as this, people end up having a kind of affection for the monsters. They end up caring about them.„

— Ishiro Honda, speaking of his film Rodan

Ishiro Honda (本多 猪四郎, Honda Ishirō) was a Japanese film director and screenwriter who is most famous for his work on various tokusatsu Toho films. During the early 1970s, he directed a few tokusatsu TV episodes for Tsuburaya Productions.
